[[File:Władysław Konopczyński.png|thumb|Władysław Konopczyński.]] '''Władysław Konopczyński''' (26 November 1880 in [[Warsaw]] – 12 July 1952) was a leading Polish historian<ref name="ReferenceA">''[[Encyklopedia Polski]]'', p. 305.</ref> and publisher of primary-source materials.<ref name="PWN p. 539">''Encyklopedia powszechna PWN'', vol. 2, p. 539.</ref>
==Life== Władysław Konopczyński was born on 26 November 1880 in Warsaw as a son of Ignacy and Ludwika. He was baptised as Władysław Aleksander. His godsparents were Zofia Strumiłło and Aleksander Konopczyński.<ref>P. Biliński, Władysław Konopczyński w kręgu naukowym i rodzinnym. In: Władysław Konopczyński 1880–1952. Materiały z posiedzenia naukowego PAU w dniu 21 czerwca 2002 r., zebrał i opracował J. A. Gierowski, Kraków 2005, p. 85.</ref>
Konopczyński was a student of Polish historian [[Szymon Askenazy]].<ref>''[[Encyklopedia Polski]]'', p. 305</ref> He became a professor at [[Kraków]]'s [[Jagiellonian University]] (1917) and a member of the [[Warsaw Scientific Society]] (''Towarzystwo Naukowe Warszawskie'') and the [[Polish Academy of Learning]] (''Polska Akademia Umiejętności'', 1922).<ref name="PWN p. 539"/>
He was a polyglot who knew 14 languages.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Biliński|first1=Piotr|title=Władysław Konopczyński: historyk i polityk II Rzeczypospolitej (1880-1952)|date=1999|location=Warszawa|pages=25}}</ref>
Konopczyński's chief interests were Polish parliamentary history, 17th- and 18th-century Polish politics and political thought, and the [[Bar Confederation]]. He wrote histories of Poland and of the modern world.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> In his own time, he participated as a member of the Polish delegation at the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Romer|first1=Eugeniusz|title=Pamiętnik Paryski 1918-1919.}}</ref> and as a representative of [[Popular National Union]] in the Sejm between 1922 and 1927 during the [[Second Polish Republic]]. He argued for the recognition of the role of [[Roman Dmowski]] in the fight for Polish independence.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Konopczyński|first1=Władysław|title=O Miejscu dla Dmowskiego w Historii|url=http://www.romandmowski.pl/default.php?id=18&dzial=odmowskim=1}}</ref>
In 1931, he founded [[Polish Biographical Dictionary|''Polski słownik biograficzny'']] (The Polish Biographical Dictionary) and served as its first editor, seeing seven volumes through press, 1935–1949, before being forced by Poland's postwar communist government to resign his editorship.<ref name="ReferenceA" /><ref name="PWN p. 539"/> Many of his former and contemporary students also contributed to this work, including [[Emanuel Rostworowski]], [[Władysław Czapliński]], [[Józef Feldman]], and [[Józef Andrzej Gierowski]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=(ed.) Prosińska-Jackl|first1=Maria|title=Słownik historyków polskich}}</ref>
During [[World War II]], Konoczyński survived German imprisonment at [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp]].<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Released in February 1940, he returned to Kraków where he continued to teach history secretly, rebuking those who claimed that the circumstances of the war kept them from their studies.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rostworowski|first1=Emanuel|title=Afterward to "Fryderyk Wielki a Polska"}}</ref>
After the war, he was removed from all his academic and scholarly posts by Poland's communist government.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
Konopczyński was a recipient of the [[France|French]] ''[[Légion d'honneur]]''.
==Works== His chief works included: *''Polska w dobie wojny siedmioletniej'' (Poland during the [[Seven Years' War]], 1909–11); *''[[Liberum veto]]'' (1918); *''Dzieje Polski nowożytnej'' (History of Modern Poland, 2 vols., 1936); *''Konfederacja barska'' (The [[Bar Confederation]], 1936–38);<ref name="ReferenceA" /> *''Kwestia bałtycka do XIX wieku'' (The Baltic Question to the 19th Century, 1947).<ref name="PWN p. 539"/> *''Fryderyk Wielki a Polska'' (Frederick the Great and Poland) (1947, republished in 2010) *''Polska a Szwecja'' (Poland and Sweden) (1924) *''Polska a Turcja 1683-1792'' (Poland and Turkey 1683-1792) (1936) *''Anglia a Polska w XVIII wieku'' (England and Poland in the 18th century)(1947)
